title: Letters to the editor Sunday
text:
Forum truly captures 'voice' of Savannah
Tuesday evening (Oct. 20) was Emergent Savannah’s event, “Turning the Tables: A (Local) World Cafe with Savannah Candidates,” held at the Creative Coast’s Creators’ Foundry.
I attended, along with approximately 100 other voters and most (if not all) of the Savannah City Council and mayoral candidates and incumbents.
What set this event apart from the majority of debates and forums over the last couple of months was the fact that we were sitting in groups of six to eight with the candidates and incumbents in a round-table “conversation” style. Nothing prepared — no podiums, no microphones, no moderators — simply voters from all ages and races sitting together with candidates/incumbents speaking as if we were all at the dinner table together.
We were allowed 12 minutes in each group and then moved on to another group while the candidates remained in their seats for a total of four rounds.
I arrived with trepidation, but found myself comfortable asking questions and speaking freely in what would normally have been an intimidating situation. This type of “conversation” allowed for an intimate setting for learning and discussing our city’s biggest issues.
Even Mayor Edna Jackson herself praised Emergent Savannah for this style of discussion. It truly reflected Emergent Savannah’s vision: “Culture. Community. Conversation.”
I feel that City Council might consider utilizing this method of communication with their constituents for effective decision-making. The more intimate and personal format truly captures the “voice” of Savannah’s citizens.
Savannah is two weeks away from a historical election.
Thank you, Emergent Savannah, for bringing together voters and candidates in this welcoming “world cafe” Tuesday evening.
JAMIE SMITH ARKINS
Savannah
Letter writer learned a lot from candidate forum
Emergent Savannah’s innovative “Turning the Tables” meet the candidates event was a breath of fresh air in a busy City Council election season filled with conventional candidate forums and one-minute answers to complicated questions.
Instead of sitting passively in an audience, attendees had an opportunity to speak and listen to candidates and fellow citizens in intimate conversation circles. I didn’t meet all the candidates there, but I had some interesting conversations and learned a lot.
KAREN GRAINEY
Savannah
We should consolidate the city, county
Are you as tired as I am of the endless bickering between our elected officials?
When Chatham County was made up of distinct urban and rural areas, it made sense to have our government divided between the cities and the county. That structure gave each area representation consistent with its residents — city dwellers and farmers.
Now, with the majority of the area being urban and suburban, does this still work? Based on the long ongoing inability of the city of Savannah and Chatham County to come to a working agreement for our police force, I don’t believe this split form of government serves our citizens well.
Let us citizens start and demand a vigorous, yet civil debate about consolidating the city of Savannah and Chatham County into one municipal government. We should all have a voice in how this entire community is governed. Segmented government isn’t working.
If you agree, call or write your local representative. I’m doing just that today.
JOHNNY PARKER
Savannah
City should replace historic bulbs
It’s great that Georgia Power has replaced its high pressure sodium street lighting with LEDs — all 16,164 of them.
However, what about the city-owned, historic lamp posts in and around most of our downtown squares? While they are certainly more attractive than the “poles” by Georgia Power, their illumination is still the “orange/pink” glow.
When will the city officials follow the lead to LED by Georgia Power, and replace the bulbs in their lamp posts with security enhancing and night sky friendly LED lighting?
TED J. KLEISNER
Savannah
